column3: NAK for "Grammer", ACK for "fixed non-sensical error message"\n
Sure, I'll delete "grammer" if that's the consensus.\n
Not sure whether it's intentional or not, but it's called "grammar" in English.\n
I need to follow this up for the pull request "Me and my buddies fixed them spelling."\n
NACK, as he included an already merged commit.\n
@retep You have to rebase to current master, so that only your commit goes into this pull-req.\ne.g. rebase origin upstream\n

@Diapolo Thanks. I think I fixed it.

Sorry, this is the first time I've used github pull requests before.
Looks good now :) and I had a hard time learning Git, too ... don't worry.\n
See my update below for a better version. Also a small grammer fix.\n
Should read "Add a n-required...", as "an" goes before words that begin with vowels. Perhaps the devs intended to use the spelling "nrequired"?\n

Ha, yeah you're right. Elementary school was  a long time ago...

The term nrequired is always capitalized as nRequired elsewhere in the code, so I think it's meant to read as two words.
n is just the prefix given to variable names that hold numbers\n

Ahh, Hungarian.

Since it's user facing though, I'd still use the english writing convention of n-required for the rpc docs.
